See also: januar, janúar, and január

German[edit]

Alternative forms[edit]

  • Jänner

Etymology[edit]

From Latin iānuārius.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈjanuaːr/, /ˈjanuaː(ɐ̯)/ (standard)
  • IPA(key): /ˈjanʊɐ̯/, /ˈjaːnʊɐ̯/ (colloquial, regional)
  • audio
    		(file)

Noun[edit]

Januar m (genitive Januars or Januar, plural Januare)

  1. January

Declension[edit]

Declension of Januar
singularplural
indef.def.noundef.noun
nominativeeinderJanuardieJanuare
genitiveeinesdesJanuars,
Januar		derJanuare
dativeeinemdemJanuardenJanuaren
accusativeeinendenJanuardieJanuare

Descendants[edit]

  • → Estonian: jaanuar
  • → Hebrew: יָנוּאָר‎ (yánuar)
  • → Yiddish: יאַנואַר‎ (yanuar)

Further reading[edit]

  • Januar in Duden online

Hunsrik[edit]

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈja(ː)nuaː/

Noun[edit]

Januar m (plural Januar)

  1. January
    In Januar is-es immer aarich heis.
    It's always very hot in January.

Further reading[edit]

  • Online Hunsrik Dictionary

Luxembourgish[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From German Januar, from Latin ianuarius.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈja.nuˌaː(ʀ)/, [ˈjɑ.nuˌaː(χ)]

Noun[edit]

Januar m (plural Januaren)

  1. January

See also[edit]

  • (Gregorian calendar months) Mount am Gregorianesche Kalenner; Januar, Februar, Mäerz, Abrëll, Mee, Juni, Juli, August, September, Oktober, November, Dezember (Category: lb:Months)

Scots[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle English Januarie, januari, re-latinised forms of Middle English Janevere, Ieneuer, from Anglo-Norman genever, from Latin iānuārius (“(month) of Janus”), perhaps from a Proto-Indo-European *h₁ey- (“to go”, a root).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): [ˈdʒanwər]

Proper noun[edit]

Januar

  1. January

See also[edit]

  • (Gregorian calendar months) Januar, Februar, Mairch, Apryle, Mey, Juin, Julie, August, September, October, November, December (Category: sco:Gregorian calendar months)
